 Perhaps I'm hypersensitive, but I get twitchy when people talk about 'believing in' (or not believing in) evolution. You 'believe in' something either through faith (god, the tooth fairy) or through conviction of its propriety (democracy, human rights, justice). Neither should apply to a scientific theory, which is accepted or not to an extent dependent on the supporting evidence.
 
 It makes no sense to say you do or don't 'believe in' general relativity or quantum mechanics: if you are able, you weigh up the evidence for those theories' claims and come to a judgement of their worth based on that. Why should the theory of evolution be treated differently?
 
 A disingenuous question, of course. It's treated differently only by people whose literalist religious beliefs are threatened by it, and who must of necessity ignore the overwhelming supporting evidence and misrepresent its acceptance as a matter of faith that they are then able to deny. We should leave the vocabulary of 'belief in' evolution to them.

They may do this quite deliberately in order to confuse the basis of scientific knowledge with the "metaphysical" sources of their belief system; and, as you imply, this could result in a fatuous attempt to discredit or to misrepresent science.
 
 Others simply don't understand that the (falsifiable) hypotheses generated from a scientific theory are not matters of conjecture, personal opinion, etc., but consist of syntheses of data which have been verified through empirical observation.
